text.p: These are the leading stories in the Malawi press on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The High Court in Blantyre ruled that 1997 university entrance selection be based on results of the first entrance examination held in January this year.

- Opposition Social Democratic Party President Eston Kakhome urged the country's two big opposition parties, Malawi Congress Party and Alliance for Democracy to speed up their proposed merger to make way for those wishing to revive the original parties.

- Former presidential economic advisor Kalonga Stambuli has been denied bail in connection with his arrest for the dissappearance of $22,667 from President Bakili Muluzi's International Appeal Fund for Clean Water.
- The Lilongwe Water Board cut the water supply to the Malawi army headquarters in Lilongwe on Tuesday becasue of an oustanding bill of seven million kwacha ($467,000).

- Police had not yet established a case against former presidential economic advisor Kalonga Stambuli when they arrested him on Saturday, prosecutor Jones Moroko told Blantyre's Magistrate Court on Tuesday.
- Two South Africans have been sentenced to two and half years in jail by a Lilongwe magistrate for possession of marijuana.
- The government has dropped court charges against former president Kamuzu Banda and his associates in a fraud case of more than 135 million kwacha ($9 million).
- The anti-corruption bureau has been flooded with more than 1,000 complaints about corruption in the public and private sectors, bureau director Gilton Chiwula said.
